raw_text:
Solskjaer raises hopes of return
 
 Manchester United striker Ole Gunnar Solskjaer said he hoped to return next season following a career-threatening injury to his right knee.
 
 The 31-year-old Norway international had surgery in Sweden in August to transplant cartilage into the joint. "I'm in no doubt that I'll play again," Solskjaer told Aftenposten Daily. "The problem will be the speed but we're talking about eight months' time. It's going as it should with the knee. I'm slavishly following a programme." Solskjaer last played for United as a late substitute in May's FA Cup final win over Millwall. His contract with United runs out in 2006, by which time he will have been at the Premier League club for 10 years.
llama3.2:1b: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer has surgery on his right knee and hopes to return next season.
llama3.2:3b: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer hopes to return next season after a career-threatening injury to his right knee, and is following a rehabilitation programme that should see him back on the field in eight months.

qwen2.5:0.5b: Manchester United striker Ole Gunnar Solskjaer expressed optimism for his return to the Premier League after suffering a career-threatening injury to his right knee during a surgery in August. He stated that playing again would be "in no doubt" and referred to it as "speed." Despite being out for eight months, he is determined to play with a team of 10 years' service remaining, having only been at the club for 10 years.

He previously played in May's FA Cup final replacement and has until the end of his contract to renew his association with the club that spans 10 seasons.
qwen2.5:3b: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, 31, expressed hope to return to Manchester United next season after knee surgery. He plans to play again within eight months following cartilage transplant in August. Currently slavishly following a recovery programme, he last played for United as a substitute in the May FA Cup final. His contract with the club expires in 2006, marking his tenth year at the Premier League club.
opencoder:1.5b:
Solskjaer raises hopes of returning to the footballing world

Manchester United striker Ole Gunnar Solskjaer said he was hopeful to retire next season following a recent injury to his right ankle. The former player had undergone a cartilage transplants in Sweden, and "I am confident I will be able to return" to the sport with him.
smollm:1.7b: Solskjaer hopes to return next season after surgery on his right knee. He is confident that he can play again and has a plan to do so. The injury was severe but the surgery was successful, and Solskjaer is optimistic about the outcome. He will be in no doubt that he will play next season and is willing to work hard to get back into form quickly.

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer hopes to return to Manchester United after a career-threatening injury to his right knee. He underwent surgery in Sweden to replace cartilage with transplants, stating he's "in no doubt" he'll play again but expects it in eight months due to speed issues. He last played as a substitute for Millwall in May and will return next season. Solskjaer was at Manchester United since 1985, having joined when he was 26.
tinyllama:1.1b: In light of Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's recent successful surgery on his right knee, the Norwegian midfielder has stated that he hopes to return to United in a future season following a career-threatening injury. The club's manager, Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, is confident that Solskjaer will play again and has given instructions to prepare for it. While no specific timeline has been provided for his recovery, Solskjaer has stated that he expects to be back within eight months with the help of a rehabilitation program. As of now, Solskjaer is still under contract with United for 10 years and will need to be at the club for another five before any discussions could take place about a possible return to play.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Manchester United's striker Ole Gunnar Solskjaer hopes to return next season following a career-threatening injury to his right knee. He underwent surgery in Sweden to transplant cartilage into the joint, and is optimistic about his recovery. Speaking to Aftenposten Daily, Solskjaer expressed confidence that he will play again, citing a "slavish" approach to rehabilitation. His contract at Manchester United expires in 2006, and he could make his return as a substitute in the club's FA Cup final win over Millwall on May 18.
